linegroup.line: More hair than wit? It may be; I'll prove it. The
cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it
is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit
is more than the wit, for the greater hides the
less. What's next?

linegroup.speaker: SPEED
linegroup.line: 'And more faults than hairs,'--

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: That's monstrous: O, that that were out!

linegroup.speaker: SPEED
linegroup.line: 'And more wealth than faults.'

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well,
I'll have her; and if it be a match, as nothing is
impossible,--

linegroup.speaker: SPEED
linegroup.line: What then?

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: Why, then will I tell thee--that thy master stays
for thee at the North-gate.

linegroup.speaker: SPEED
linegroup.line: For me?

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: For thee! ay, who art thou? he hath stayed for a
better man than thee.

linegroup.speaker: SPEED
linegroup.line: And must I go to him?

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long
that going will scarce serve the turn.

linegroup.speaker: SPEED
linegroup.line: Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love letters!

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an
unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into
secrets! I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.

section.title: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you,
Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Since his exile she hath despised me most,
Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,
That I am desperate of obtaining her.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: This weak impress of love is as a figure
Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat
Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts
And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.
How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman
According to our proclamation gone?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Gone, my good lord.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: My daughter takes his going grievously.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so.
Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee--
For thou hast shown some sign of good desert--
Makes me the better to confer with thee.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Longer than I prove loyal to your grace
Let me not live to look upon your grace.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Thou know'st how willingly I would effect
The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: I do, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant
How she opposes her against my will

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Ay, and perversely she persevers so.
What might we do to make the girl forget
The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: The best way is to slander Valentine
With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent,
Three things that women highly hold in hate.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Ay, if his enemy deliver it:
Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Then you must undertake to slander him.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do:
'Tis an ill office for a gentleman,
Especially against his very friend.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Where your good word cannot advantage him,
Your slander never can endamage him;
Therefore the office is indifferent,
Being entreated to it by your friend.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: You have prevail'd, my lord; if I can do it
By ought that I can speak in his dispraise,
She shall not long continue love to him.
But say this weed her love from Valentine,
It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him,
Lest it should ravel and be good to none,
You must provide to bottom it on me;
Which must be done by praising me as much
As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,
Because we know, on Valentine's report,
You are already Love's firm votary
And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.
Upon this warrant shall you have access
Where you with Silvia may confer at large;
For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,
And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you;
Where you may temper her by your persuasion
To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: As much as I can do, I will effect:
But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough;
You must lay lime to tangle her desires
By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes
Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Ay,
Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Say that upon the altar of her beauty
You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:
Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears
Moist it again, and frame some feeling line
That may discover such integrity:
For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews,
Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones,
Make tigers tame and huge leviathans
Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.
After your dire-lamenting elegies,
Visit by night your lady's chamber-window
With some sweet concert; to their instruments
Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence
Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.
This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: And thy advice this night I'll put in practise.
Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver,
Let us into the city presently
To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.
I have a sonnet that will serve the turn
To give the onset to thy good advice.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: About it, gentlemen!

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: We'll wait upon your grace till after supper,
And afterward determine our proceedings.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Even now about it! I will pardon you.

section.title: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em.

linegroup.speaker: Third Outlaw
linegroup.line: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye:
If not: we'll make you sit and rifle you.

linegroup.speaker: SPEED
linegroup.line: Sir, we are undone; these are the villains
That all the travellers do fear so much.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: My friends,--

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: That's not so, sir: we are your enemies.

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: Peace! we'll hear him.

linegroup.speaker: Third Outlaw
linegroup.line: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he's a proper man.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Then know that I have little wealth to lose:
A man I am cross'd with adversity;
My riches are these poor habiliments,
Of which if you should here disfurnish me,
You take the sum and substance that I have.

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: Whither travel you?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: To Verona.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: Whence came you?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: From Milan.

linegroup.speaker: Third Outlaw
linegroup.line: Have you long sojourned there?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay'd,
If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: What, were you banish'd thence?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: I was.

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: For what offence?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: For that which now torments me to rehearse:
I kill'd a man, whose death I much repent;
But yet I slew him manfully in fight,
Without false vantage or base treachery.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so.
But were you banish'd for so small a fault?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: Have you the tongues?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: My youthful travel therein made me happy,
Or else I often had been miserable.

linegroup.speaker: Third Outlaw
linegroup.line: By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar,
This fellow were a king for our wild faction!

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.

linegroup.speaker: SPEED
linegroup.line: Master, be one of them; it's an honourable kind of thievery.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Peace, villain!

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Nothing but my fortune.

linegroup.speaker: Third Outlaw
linegroup.line: Know, then, that some of us are gentlemen,
Such as the fury of ungovern'd youth
Thrust from the company of awful men:
Myself was from Verona banished
For practising to steal away a lady,
An heir, and near allied unto the duke.

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: And I from Mantua, for a gentleman,
Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: And I for such like petty crimes as these,
But to the purpose--for we cite our faults,
That they may hold excus'd our lawless lives;
And partly, seeing you are beautified
With goodly shape and by your own report
A linguist and a man of such perfection
As we do in our quality much want--

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: Indeed, because you are a banish'd man,
Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you:
Are you content to be our general?
To make a virtue of necessity
And live, as we do, in this wilderness?

linegroup.speaker: Third Outlaw
linegroup.line: What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort?
Say ay, and be the captain of us all:
We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee,
Love thee as our commander and our king.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: I take your offer and will live with you,
Provided that you do no outrages
On silly women or poor passengers.

linegroup.speaker: Third Outlaw
linegroup.line: No, we detest such vile base practises.
Come, go with us, we'll bring thee to our crews,
And show thee all the treasure we have got,
Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.

section.title: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Already have I been false to Valentine
And now I must be as unjust to Thurio.
Under the colour of commending him,
I have access my own love to prefer:
But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy,
To be corrupted with my worthless gifts.
When I protest true loyalty to her,
She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;
When to her beauty I commend my vows,
She bids me think how I have been forsworn
In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved:
And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,
The least whereof would quell a lover's hope,
Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love,
The more it grows and fawneth on her still.
But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window,
And give some evening music to her ear.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Ay, gentle Thurio: for you know that love
Will creep in service where it cannot go.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Sir, but I do; or else I would be hence.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Who? Silvia?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Ay, Silvia; for your sake.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen,
Let's tune, and to it lustily awhile.

section.para: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly: I
pray you, why is it?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Come, we'll have you merry: I'll bring you where
you shall hear music and see the gentleman that you asked for.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: But shall I hear him speak?

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Ay, that you shall.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: That will be music.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Hark, hark!

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Is he among these?

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Ay: but, peace! let's hear 'em.
Who is Silvia? what is she,
That all our swains commend her?
Holy, fair and wise is she;
The heaven such grace did lend her,
That she might admired be.
Is she kind as she is fair?
For beauty lives with kindness.
Love doth to her eyes repair,
To help him of his blindness,
And, being help'd, inhabits there.
Then to Silvia let us sing,
That Silvia is excelling;
She excels each mortal thing
Upon the dull earth dwelling:
To her let us garlands bring.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: How now! are you sadder than you were before? How
do you, man? the music likes you not.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: You mistake; the musician likes me not.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Why, my pretty youth?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: He plays false, father.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: How? out of tune on the strings?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Not so; but yet so false that he grieves my very
heart-strings.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: You have a quick ear.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Ay, I would I were deaf; it makes me have a slow heart.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: I perceive you delight not in music.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Not a whit, when it jars so.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Hark, what fine change is in the music!

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Ay, that change is the spite.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: You would have them always play but one thing?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: I would always have one play but one thing.
But, host, doth this Sir Proteus that we talk on
Often resort unto this gentlewoman?

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: I tell you what Launce, his man, told me: he loved
her out of all nick.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Where is Launce?

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Gone to seek his dog; which tomorrow, by his
master's command, he must carry for a present to his lady.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Peace! stand aside: the company parts.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Sir Thurio, fear not you: I will so plead
That you shall say my cunning drift excels.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Where meet we?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: At Saint Gregory's well.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Farewell.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Madam, good even to your ladyship.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: I thank you for your music, gentlemen.
Who is that that spake?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: One, lady, if you knew his pure heart's truth,
You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Sir Proteus, as I take it.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Sir Proteus, gentle lady, and your servant.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: What's your will?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: That I may compass yours.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: You have your wish; my will is even this:
That presently you hie you home to bed.
Thou subtle, perjured, false, disloyal man!
Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless,
To be seduced by thy flattery,
That hast deceived so many with thy vows?
Return, return, and make thy love amends.
For me, by this pale queen of night I swear,
I am so far from granting thy request
That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit,
And by and by intend to chide myself
Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: I grant, sweet love, that I did love a lady;
But she is dead.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside 'Twere false, if I should speak it;
For I am sure she is not buried.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend
Survives; to whom, thyself art witness,
I am betroth'd: and art thou not ashamed
To wrong him with thy importunacy?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: And so suppose am I; for in his grave
Assure thyself my love is buried.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence,
Or, at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside He heard not that.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Madam, if your heart be so obdurate,
Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love,
The picture that is hanging in your chamber;
To that I'll speak, to that I'll sigh and weep:
For since the substance of your perfect self
Is else devoted, I am but a shadow;
And to your shadow will I make true love.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside If 'twere a substance, you would, sure,
deceive it,
And make it but a shadow, as I am.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: I am very loath to be your idol, sir;
But since your falsehood shall become you well
To worship shadows and adore false shapes,
Send to me in the morning and I'll send it:
And so, good rest.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: As wretches have o'ernight
That wait for execution in the morn.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Host, will you go?

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: By my halidom, I was fast asleep.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Marry, at my house. Trust me, I think 'tis almost
day.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Not so; but it hath been the longest night
That e'er I watch'd and the most heaviest.

section.title: SCENE III. The same.

linegroup.speaker: EGLAMOUR
linegroup.line: This is the hour that Madam Silvia
Entreated me to call and know her mind:
There's some great matter she'ld employ me in.
Madam, madam!

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Who calls?

linegroup.speaker: EGLAMOUR
linegroup.line: Your servant and your friend;
One that attends your ladyship's command.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.

linegroup.speaker: EGLAMOUR
linegroup.line: As many, worthy lady, to yourself:
According to your ladyship's impose,
I am thus early come to know what service
It is your pleasure to command me in.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman--
Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not--
Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplish'd:
Thou art not ignorant what dear good will
I bear unto the banish'd Valentine,
Nor how my father would enforce me marry
Vain Thurio, whom my very soul abhors.
Thyself hast loved; and I have heard thee say
No grief did ever come so near thy heart
As when thy lady and thy true love died,
Upon whose grave thou vow'dst pure chastity.
Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine,
To Mantua, where I hear he makes abode;
And, for the ways are dangerous to pass,
I do desire thy worthy company,
Upon whose faith and honour I repose.
Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour,
But think upon my grief, a lady's grief,
And on the justice of my flying hence,
To keep me from a most unholy match,
Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues.
I do desire thee, even from a heart
As full of sorrows as the sea of sands,
To bear me company and go with me:
If not, to hide what I have said to thee,
That I may venture to depart alone.

linegroup.speaker: EGLAMOUR
linegroup.line: Madam, I pity much your grievances;
Which since I know they virtuously are placed,
I give consent to go along with you,
Recking as little what betideth me
As much I wish all good befortune you.
When will you go?

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: This evening coming.

linegroup.speaker: EGLAMOUR
linegroup.line: Where shall I meet you?

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: At Friar Patrick's cell,
Where I intend holy confession.

linegroup.speaker: EGLAMOUR
linegroup.line: I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow, gentle lady.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.

section.title: SCENE IV. The same.
section.para: Enter LAUNCE, with his his Dog

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: When a man's servant shall play the cur with him,
look you, it goes hard: one that I brought up of a
puppy; one that I saved from drowning, when three or
four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it.
I have taught him, even as one would say precisely,
'thus I would teach a dog.' I was sent to deliver
him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master;
and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he
steps me to her trencher and steals her capon's leg:
O, 'tis a foul thing when a cur cannot keep himself
in all companies! I would have, as one should say,
one that takes upon him to be a dog indeed, to be,
as it were, a dog at all things. If I had not had
more wit than he, to take a fault upon me that he did,
I think verily he had been hanged for't; sure as I
live, he had suffered for't; you shall judge. He
thrusts me himself into the company of three or four
gentlemanlike dogs under the duke's table: he had
not been there--bless the mark!--a pissing while, but
all the chamber smelt him. 'Out with the dog!' says
one: 'What cur is that?' says another: 'Whip him
out' says the third: 'Hang him up' says the duke.
I, having been acquainted with the smell before,
knew it was Crab, and goes me to the fellow that
whips the dogs: 'Friend,' quoth I, 'you mean to whip
the dog?' 'Ay, marry, do I,' quoth he. 'You do him
the more wrong,' quoth I; ''twas I did the thing you
wot of.' He makes me no more ado, but whips me out
of the chamber. How many masters would do this for
his servant? Nay, I'll be sworn, I have sat in the
stocks for puddings he hath stolen, otherwise he had
been executed; I have stood on the pillory for geese
he hath killed, otherwise he had suffered for't.
Thou thinkest not of this now. Nay, I remember the
trick you served me when I took my leave of Madam
Silvia: did not I bid thee still mark me and do as I
do? when didst thou see me heave up my leg and make
water against a gentlewoman's farthingale? didst
thou ever see me do such a trick?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well
And will employ thee in some service presently.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: In what you please: I'll do what I can.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: I hope thou wilt.
How now, you whoreson peasant!
Where have you been these two days loitering?

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: And what says she to my little jewel?

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells you
currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: But she received my dog?

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: No, indeed, did she not: here have I brought him
back again.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

linegroup.speaker: LAUNCE
linegroup.line: Ay, sir: the other squirrel was stolen from me by
the hangman boys in the market-place: and then I
offered her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of
yours, and therefore the gift the greater.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Go get thee hence, and find my dog again,
Or ne'er return again into my sight.
Away, I say! stay'st thou to vex me here?
A slave, that still an end turns me to shame!
Sebastian, I have entertained thee,
Partly that I have need of such a youth
That can with some discretion do my business,
For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout,
But chiefly for thy face and thy behavior,
Which, if my augury deceive me not,
Witness good bringing up, fortune and truth:
Therefore know thou, for this I entertain thee.
Go presently and take this ring with thee,
Deliver it to Madam Silvia:
She loved me well deliver'd it to me.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token.
She is dead, belike?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Not so; I think she lives.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Alas!

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Why dost thou cry 'alas'?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: I cannot choose
But pity her.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Because methinks that she loved you as well
As you do love your lady Silvia:
She dreams of him that has forgot her love;
You dote on her that cares not for your love.
'Tis pity love should be so contrary;
And thinking of it makes me cry 'alas!'

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Well, give her that ring and therewithal
This letter. That's her chamber. Tell my lady
I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.
Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,
Where thou shalt find me, sad and solitary.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: How many women would do such a message?
Alas, poor Proteus! thou hast entertain'd
A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs.
Alas, poor fool! why do I pity him
That with his very heart despiseth me?
Because he loves her, he despiseth me;
Because I love him I must pity him.
This ring I gave him when he parted from me,
To bind him to remember my good will;
And now am I, unhappy messenger,
To plead for that which I would not obtain,
To carry that which I would have refused,
To praise his faith which I would have dispraised.
I am my master's true-confirmed love;
But cannot be true servant to my master,
Unless I prove false traitor to myself.
Yet will I woo for him, but yet so coldly
As, heaven it knows, I would not have him speed.
Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you, be my mean
To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: What would you with her, if that I be she?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: If you be she, I do entreat your patience
To hear me speak the message I am sent on.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: From whom?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: O, he sends you for a picture.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Ay, madam.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Ursula, bring my picture here.
Go give your master this: tell him from me,
One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget,
Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Madam, please you peruse this letter.--
Pardon me, madam; I have unadvised
Deliver'd you a paper that I should not:
This is the letter to your ladyship.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: I pray thee, let me look on that again.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: It may not be; good madam, pardon me.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: There, hold!
I will not look upon your master's lines:
I know they are stuff'd with protestations
And full of new-found oaths; which he will break
As easily as I do tear his paper.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: The more shame for him that he sends it me;
For I have heard him say a thousand times
His Julia gave it him at his departure.
Though his false finger have profaned the ring,
Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: She thanks you.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: What say'st thou?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: I thank you, madam, that you tender her.
Poor gentlewoman! my master wrongs her much.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Dost thou know her?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Almost as well as I do know myself:
To think upon her woes I do protest
That I have wept a hundred several times.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: I think she doth; and that's her cause of sorrow.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Is she not passing fair?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is:
When she did think my master loved her well,
She, in my judgment, was as fair as you:
But since she did neglect her looking-glass
And threw her sun-expelling mask away,
The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks
And pinch'd the lily-tincture of her face,
That now she is become as black as I.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: How tall was she?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: About my stature; for at Pentecost,
When all our pageants of delight were play'd,
Our youth got me to play the woman's part,
And I was trimm'd in Madam Julia's gown,
Which served me as fit, by all men's judgments,
As if the garment had been made for me:
Therefore I know she is about my height.
And at that time I made her weep agood,
For I did play a lamentable part:
Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning
For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight;
Which I so lively acted with my tears
That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,
Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead
If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth.
Alas, poor lady, desolate and left!
I weep myself to think upon thy words.
Here, youth, there is my purse; I give thee this
For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lovest her.
Farewell.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her.
A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful
I hope my master's suit will be but cold,
Since she respects my mistress' love so much.
Alas, how love can trifle with itself!
Here is her picture: let me see; I think,
If I had such a tire, this face of mine
Were full as lovely as is this of hers:
And yet the painter flatter'd her a little,
Unless I flatter with myself too much.
Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow:
If that be all the difference in his love,
I'll get me such a colour'd periwig.
Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine:
Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high.
What should it be that he respects in her
But I can make respective in myself,
If this fond Love were not a blinded god?
Come, shadow, come and take this shadow up,
For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form,
Thou shalt be worshipp'd, kiss'd, loved and adored!
And, were there sense in his idolatry,
My substance should be statue in thy stead.
I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake,
That used me so; or else, by Jove I vow,
I should have scratch'd out your unseeing eyes
To make my master out of love with thee!

section.title: SCENE I. Milan. An abbey.

linegroup.speaker: EGLAMOUR
linegroup.line: The sun begins to gild the western sky;
And now it is about the very hour
That Silvia, at Friar Patrick's cell, should meet me.
She will not fail, for lovers break not hours,
Unless it be to come before their time;
So much they spur their expedition.
See where she comes.
Lady, a happy evening!

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour,
Out at the postern by the abbey-wall:
I fear I am attended by some spies.

linegroup.speaker: EGLAMOUR
linegroup.line: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;
If we recover that, we are sure enough.

section.title: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: O, sir, I find her milder than she was;
And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: What, that my leg is too long?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: No; that it is too little.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: I'll wear a boot, to make it somewhat rounder.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside But love will not be spurr'd to what
it loathes.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: What says she to my face?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: She says it is a fair one.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Nay then, the wanton lies; my face is black.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is,
Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside 'Tis true; such pearls as put out
ladies' eyes;
For I had rather wink than look on them.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: How likes she my discourse?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Ill, when you talk of war.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: What says she to my valour?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: What says she to my birth?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: That you are well derived.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside True; from a gentleman to a fool.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Considers she my possessions?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: O, ay; and pities them.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Wherefore?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside That such an ass should owe them.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: That they are out by lease.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Here comes the duke.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: How now, Sir Proteus! how now, Thurio!
Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Not I.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Nor I.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Saw you my daughter?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Neither.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Why then,
She's fled unto that peasant Valentine;
And Eglamour is in her company.
'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both,
As he in penance wander'd through the forest;
Him he knew well, and guess'd that it was she,
But, being mask'd, he was not sure of it;
Besides, she did intend confession
At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not;
These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.
Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse,
But mount you presently and meet with me
Upon the rising of the mountain-foot
That leads towards Mantua, whither they are fled:
Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,
That flies her fortune when it follows her.
I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour
Than for the love of reckless Silvia.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: And I will follow, more for Silvia's love
Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: And I will follow, more to cross that love
Than hate for Silvia that is gone for love.

section.title: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: Come, come,
Be patient; we must bring you to our captain.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: A thousand more mischances than this one
Have learn'd me how to brook this patiently.

linegroup.speaker: Second Outlaw
linegroup.line: Come, bring her away.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

linegroup.speaker: Third Outlaw
linegroup.line: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,
But Moyses and Valerius follow him.
Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;
There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled;
The thicket is beset; he cannot 'scape.

linegroup.speaker: First Outlaw
linegroup.line: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave:
Fear not; he bears an honourable mind,
And will not use a woman lawlessly.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!

section.title: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: How use doth breed a habit in a man!
This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods,
I better brook than flourishing peopled towns:
Here can I sit alone, unseen of any,
And to the nightingale's complaining notes
Tune my distresses and record my woes.
O thou that dost inhabit in my breast,
Leave not the mansion so long tenantless,
Lest, growing ruinous, the building fall
And leave no memory of what it was!
Repair me with thy presence, Silvia;
Thou gentle nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain!
What halloing and what stir is this to-day?
These are my mates, that make their wills their law,
Have some unhappy passenger in chase.
They love me well; yet I have much to do
To keep them from uncivil outrages.
Withdraw thee, Valentine: who's this comes here?

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Madam, this service I have done for you,
Though you respect not aught your servant doth,
To hazard life and rescue you from him
That would have forced your honour and your love;
Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look;
A smaller boon than this I cannot beg
And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Aside How like a dream is this I see and hear!
Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: O miserable, unhappy that I am!

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came;
But by my coming I have made you happy.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Aside And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: Had I been seized by a hungry lion,
I would have been a breakfast to the beast,
Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.
O, Heaven be judge how I love Valentine,
Whose life's as tender to me as my soul!
And full as much, for more there cannot be,
I do detest false perjured Proteus.
Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: What dangerous action, stood it next to death,
Would I not undergo for one calm look!
O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved,
When women cannot love where they're beloved!

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved.
Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love,
For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith
Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths
Descended into perjury, to love me.
Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two;
And that's far worse than none; better have none
Than plural faith which is too much by one:
Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: In love
Who respects friend?

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: All men but Proteus.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words
Can no way change you to a milder form,
I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end,
And love you 'gainst the nature of love,--force ye.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIA
linegroup.line: O heaven!

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: I'll force thee yield to my desire.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch,
Thou friend of an ill fashion!

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Valentine!

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love,
For such is a friend now; treacherous man!
Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye
Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say
I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.
Who should be trusted, when one's own right hand
Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus,
I am sorry I must never trust thee more,
But count the world a stranger for thy sake.
The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst,
'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: My shame and guilt confounds me.
Forgive me, Valentine: if hearty sorrow
Be a sufficient ransom for offence,
I tender 't here; I do as truly suffer
As e'er I did commit.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Then I am paid;
And once again I do receive thee honest.
Who by repentance is not satisfied
Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased.
By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased:
And, that my love may appear plain and free,
All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: O me unhappy!

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Look to the boy.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Why, boy! why, wag! how now! what's the matter?
Look up; speak.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ring
to Madam Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was never done.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Where is that ring, boy?

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Here 'tis; this is it.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: How! let me see:
Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook:
This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: But how camest thou by this ring? At my depart
I gave this unto Julia.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: And Julia herself did give it me;
And Julia herself hath brought it hither.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: How! Julia!

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths,
And entertain'd 'em deeply in her heart.
How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root!
O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush!
Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me
Such an immodest raiment, if shame live
In a disguise of love:
It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,
Women to change their shapes than men their minds.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Than men their minds! 'tis true.
O heaven! were man
But constant, he were perfect. That one error
Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins:
Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.
What is in Silvia's face, but I may spy
More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Come, come, a hand from either:
Let me be blest to make this happy close;
'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.

linegroup.speaker: PROTEUS
linegroup.line: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.

linegroup.speaker: JULIA
linegroup.line: And I mine.

section.para: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO

linegroup.speaker: Outlaws
linegroup.line: A prize, a prize, a prize!

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Forbear, forbear, I say! it is my lord the duke.
Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced,
Banished Valentine.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Sir Valentine!

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Thurio, give back, or else embrace thy death;
Come not within the measure of my wrath;
Do not name Silvia thine; if once again,
Verona shall not hold thee. Here she stands;
Take but possession of her with a touch:
I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.

linegroup.speaker: THURIO
linegroup.line: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I;
I hold him but a fool that will endanger
His body for a girl that loves him not:
I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: The more degenerate and base art thou,
To make such means for her as thou hast done
And leave her on such slight conditions.
Now, by the honour of my ancestry,
I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,
And think thee worthy of an empress' love:
Know then, I here forget all former griefs,
Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,
Plead a new state in thy unrivall'd merit,
To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine,
Thou art a gentleman and well derived;
Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy.
I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake,
To grant one boom that I shall ask of you.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: I grant it, for thine own, whate'er it be.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: These banish'd men that I have kept withal
Are men endued with worthy qualities:
Forgive them what they have committed here
And let them be recall'd from their exile:
They are reformed, civil, full of good
And fit for great employment, worthy lord.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee:
Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.
Come, let us go: we will include all jars
With triumphs, mirth and rare solemnity.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: And, as we walk along, I dare be bold
With our discourse to make your grace to smile.
What think you of this page, my lord?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE
linegroup.line: What mean you by that saying?

linegroup.speaker: VALENTINE
linegroup.line: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along,
That you will wonder what hath fortuned.
Come, Proteus; 'tis your penance but to hear
The story of your loves discovered:
That done, our day of marriage shall be yours;
One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
